DIV1.P: LONDON: PRINTED FOR C. DILLY, IN THE POULTRY, 1794.

LG.L: OUR Comic Bard, before whose roving eye
Kingdoms and States in magic vision lie,
Sweeps o'er the map, and with a partial smile
Fixes at length on his beloved Isle,
He views her deck'd in all her natural charms,
And wrapt in peace, amidst the din of arms.
"Here, here," he cries, "on ALBION's fostering breast,
"The Arts are shelter'd, and the Muses rest,
"Here I will build my stage, by moral rule
"And scenic measure here erect my school;
"A school for prejudice:—Oh! that my stroke
"Cou'd strip that creeper from the British Oak!
"Twin'd round his generous shaft, the tangled weed
"Sheds on the undergrowth it's baneful seed."
This said, he bids us strike the daring blow,
That lays his fame or this defiler low.
And now our PROLOGUE speaks—In former days
Prologues were abstracts of their several Plays;
But now, like guilty men, who dread their doom,
We talk of every thing but what's to come.
As for our Fable, little I'll unfold;
For out of little much cannot be told.
'Tis but one species in the wide extent
Of prejudice, at which our shaft is sent,
'Tis but this simple lesson of the heart—
Judge not the Man by his exterior part:
Virtue's strong root in every soil will grow,
Rich ores lie buried under piles of snow.
If to your candour we appeal this night
For a poor Client, for a luckless Wight,
Whom Bard ne'er favour'd, whose sad fate has been
Never to share in one applauding scene,
In Souls like your's there should be found a place
For every Victim of unjust disgrace.

ROW.CELL: SAUNDERS, First Clerk to SIR STEPHEN

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—An Apartment in the House of Sir STEPHEN BERTRAM.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir STEPHEN BERTRAM.
SP.P: WHY do you press me for reasons I'm not bound to give? If I chuse to dismiss an assistant clerk from my counting-house, how does it concern you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: That clerk you took at my recommenda∣tion and request; I am therefore interested to hope you have no reasons for dismissing him that affect his character.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Step.
SP.P:
I am your father, Sir, and in this house sole master; I have no partners to account to;
nor will I brook any comments on my conduct from my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Yet, as your son, may I not, without risquing your displeasure, offer one humble word upon the part of a defenceless absent friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Step.
SP.P: A friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I hope I need not blush to call Charles Ratcliffe friend. His virtues, his misfor∣tunes, his integrity, (you'll undeceive me if I err) have much endear'd him to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Step.
SP.P: Say rather his connections: Come, I see where all his friendship points—to folly, to disgrace—therefore no more of it! Break off! new friendships will not cost you dear; 'tis better you should cease to call him friend, than put it in his power to call you brother. In one word, Fre∣deric, I never will accept of Ratcliffe's sister as my daughter-in-law—nor, if I can prevent it, shall you so far forget youself as to make her your mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Mistress! Good Heaven!—But I'll restrain myself.—You never saw Miss Ratcliffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Step.
SP.P: I wish you never had—But you have seen your last of her, or me—I leave it to your choice.

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERIC.
SP.P:
I have no choice to make: she is my wife—and if to take beauty, virtue and elegance without fortune, when my father would have me take fortune without them, is a crime that merits dis∣inheritance, I must meet my punishment as I can. The only thing I dread is the severe but honorable
reproof of my friend Ratcliffe, to whom this mar∣riage is a secret, and whose distinterested resent∣ment I know not how to face: I must dissemble with him still, for I am unprepar'd with my de∣fence, and he is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Well met, Frederic!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I wish I could say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Why? what's the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I have no good news to tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I don't expect it, you are not made to be the bearer of good news; knavery engrosses all fortune's favor, and fools run up and down with the tidings of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: You are still a philosopher.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I cannot tell that till I am tried with pro∣sperity: it is that which sets our failings in full view, adversity conceals them.—But come, discuss: tell me in what one part of my composition the ingenious cruelty of Fortune can place another blow.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: By my soul, Charles, I am asham'd to tell you, because the blow is now given by a hand I wish to reverence. You know the temper of Sir Stephen Bertram: he is my father, therefore I will not enlarge upon a subject, that would be painful to us both. It is with infinite regret I have seen you (nobly descended, and still more nobly en∣dow'd) earning a scanty maintenance at your desk in his counting-house: It is a slavery you are now releas'd from.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I understand you; Sir Stephen has no fur∣ther commands for me. I will go to him, and de∣liver up my keys.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Have patience for a moment.—Do you guess his reasons for this hasty measure?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: What care I for his reasons, when I know they cannot touch my honor?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Oh! Charles, my heart is penetrated with your situation! What will become of those beloved objects—?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Why, what becomes of all the objects misery lays low? they shrink from sight, and are forgotten.—You know I will not hear you on this subject: 'twas not with my consent you ever knew there were such objects in existence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I wn it; but in this extremity methinks you might relax a little from that rigid honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Never; but as the body of a man is brac'd by winter, so is my resolution by adversity. On this point only we can differ. Why will my friend persist in urging it?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I have done. You have your way.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Then with your leave I'll go to your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Hold! Here comes one that supersedes all other visitors—old Sheva, the rich Jew, the meerest muck-worm in the city of London: How the old Hebrew casts about for prodigals to snap at! I'll throw him out a bait for sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: No, let him pass: what sport can his in∣firmities afford?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: The good day to you, my young master! How is it with your health, I pray? Is your fader Sir Stephen Bertram, and my very good patron, to be spoken with?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Yes, yes, he is at home, and to be spoken with, under some precaution, Sheva: if you bring him money, you will be welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Ah! that is very goot. Monies is wel∣come every where.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Pass on, pass on! no more apologies—Good man of money, save your breath to count your guineas. [Exit SHEVA. That fellow wou'd not let his shadow fall upon the earth, if he cou'd help it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: You are too hard upon him. The thing is courteous.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Hang him! he'll bow for half a crown. His carcase and it's covering wou'd not coin into a ducat, yet he is a moving mine of wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: You see these characters with indignation; I contemplate them with pity. I have a fellow-feel∣ing for poor Sheva: he is as much in poverty as I am, only it is poverty of another species: He wants what he has, I have nothing and want every thing. Misers are not unuseful members of the community; they act like dams to rivers, hold up the stream that else wou'd run to waste, and make deep water where there wou'd be shallows.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I recollect you was his rescuer; I did not know you were his advocate.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: 'Tis true I snatch'd him out of jeopardy. My countrymen, with all their natural humanity, have no objection to the hustling of a Jew. The poor old creature was most roughly handled.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: What was the cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P:
I never ask'd the cause: There was a hundred
upon one; that was cause enough for me to make myself a second to the party over-match'd. I got a few hard knocks, but I brought off my man.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: The synagogue shou'd cannonize you for the deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Aha! there is no business to be done; there is no talking to your fader. He is not just now in the sweetest of all possible tempers—Any thing, Mr. Bertram, wanted in my way?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Yes, Sheva, there is enough wanted in your way, but I doubt it is not in your will to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I do always do my utmost for my princi∣pals: I never spare my pains when business is going; be it ever such a trifle, I am thankful. Every little helps a poor man like me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: You speak of your spirit, I suppose, when you call yourself a poor man. All the world knows you roll in riches.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: The world knows no great deal of me: I do not deny but my monies may roll a little, but for myself I do not roll at all. I live sparingly and labor hard, therefore I am called a miser—I cannot help it—an uncharitable dog, I must endure it—a blood-sucker, an extortioner, a Shylock—hard names, Mr. Frederic, but what can a poor Jew say in return, if a Christian chuses to abuse him?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Say nothing, but spend your money like a Christian.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
We have no abiding place on earth, no country, no home: every body rails at us, every body flouts us, every body points us out for their
may-game and their mockery. If your play∣writers want a butt or a buffoon, or a knave to make sport of, out comes a Jew to be baited and buffetted through five long acts for the amusement of all good Christians—Cruel sport, merciless amuse∣ment! hard dealings for a poor stray sheep of the scatter'd flock of Abraham! How can you expect us to shew kindness, when we receive none?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: That is true, friend Sheva, I can witness; I am sorry to say there is too much justice in your complaint.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Bless this goot light! I did not see you—'Tis my very good friend Mr. Ratcliffe, as I live. Give me your pardon, I pray you, sir, give me your pardon; I should be sorry to say in your hearing that there is no charity for the poor Jews. Truly, sir, I am under very great obligations to you for your generous protection t'other night, when I was mob'd and mal-treated, and, for aught I can tell, should have been massacred, had not you stood for∣ward in my defence. Truly, sir, I bear it very thank∣fully in my remembrance; truly I do, yes truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Leave me with him, Charles: I'll hold him in discourse whilst you go to my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Oh! it was goot deed, very goot deed, to save a poor Jew from a pitiless mob, and I am very very grateful to you, worthy Mr.—Ah! the gentleman is gone away: that is another thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: It is so, but your gratitude need not go away at the same time; you are not bound to make good the proverb—"Out of sight, out of mind."

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: No, no, no; I am very much oblig'd to him, not only for my life, but for the monies and the valuables I had about me: I had been hustled out of them all but for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Well then, having so much gratitude for his favours, you have now an opportunity of mak∣ing some return to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Yes, yes, and I do make him a return of my thanks and goot wishes very heartily. What can a poor Jew say more? I do wish him all goot things, and give him all goot words.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Good words indeed! What are they to a man, who is cast naked upon the wide world, with a widow'd mother and a defenceless sister, who look up to him for their support?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Good lack, good lack! I thought he was in occupations in your fader's counting-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: He was, and from his scanty pittance piously supported those poor destitutes: that source is now stopp'd, and as you, when in the midst of rioters, was in want of a protector, so is he in the midst of his misfortunes in want of some kind friend to rescue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Oh dear, oh dear! This world is full of sadness and of sorrow; miseries upon miseries; unfortunates by hundreds and thousands, and poor Sheva has but two weak eyes to find tears for them all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P:
Come, come, Sheva, pity will not feed the hungry, nor clothe the naked. Ratcliffe is the friend of my heart: I am helpless in myself; my father, though just, is austere in the extreme;
I dare not resort to him for money, nor can I turn my thoughts to any other quarter for the loan of a small sum in this extremity, except to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: To me! goot lack, to me! What will be∣come of me? what will Sir Stephen say? He is full of monies; but then again he is a close man, very austere, as you say, and very just, but not very generous.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Well, well, let me have your answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Yes, yes, but my answer will not please you without the monies: I shall be a Jewish dog, a baboon, an imp of Beelzebub, if I don't find the monies; and when my monies is all gone, what shall I be then? An ass, a fool, a jack-a-dandy! Oh dear! oh dear!—Well, there must be conditions, look you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: To be sure: security twice secur'd; pre∣mium and interest, and bond and judgment into the bargain: only enable me to preserve my friend, give me that transort, and I care not what I pay for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Mercy on your heart! What haste and hurry you are in. How much did you want? One hundred pounds, did you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: More than one, more than one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Ah, poor Sheva! More than one hundred pounds! What! so much as two hundred? 'Tis a great deal of monies.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Come, friend Sheva, at one word—three hundred pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Mercies defend me, what a sum!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P:
Accommodate me with three hundred
pounds; make your own terms; consult your con∣science in the bargain, and I will say you are a good fellow. Oh! Sheva, did you but know the luxury of relieving honor, innocence and beauty from distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Oh! 'tis great luxury I dare say, else you wou'd not buy it at so high a price. Well, well, well! I have thought a little, and if you will come to my poor cabin in Duke's Place, you shall have the monies.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Well said, my gallant Sheva! Shall I bring a bond with me to fill up?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: No, no, no: we have all those in my shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I don't doubt it—All the apparatus of an usurer [aside.]—Farewell, Sheva! be ready with your instruments, I care not what they are: only let me have the money, and you may proceed to dissection as soon after as you please.

Heigho! I cannot chuse but weep—Sheva, thou art a fool—Three hundred pounds by the day, how much is that in the year?—Oh dear, oh dear! I shall be ruin'd, starv'd, wasted to a watch-light. Bowels, you shall pinch for this: I'll not eat flesh this fortnight; I'll suck the air for nourishment; I'll feed upon the steam of an alderman's kitchen, as I put my nose down his area.—Well, well! but soft, a word, friend Sheva! Art thou not rich? monstrous rich, abominably rich? and yet thou livest on a crust—Be it so! thou dost stint thine appe∣tites to pamper thine affections; thou dost make
thyself to live in poverty, that the poor may live in plenty. Well, well! so long as thou art a miser only to thine own cost, thou may'st hug thyself in this poor habit, and set the world's contempt at naught.
SP.STAGE: CHARLES RATCLIFFE enters, and speaks without noticing tbe JEW.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Unfeeling, heartless man, I've done with you. I'll dig, beg, perish, rather than submit to such unnatural terms—I may remain: my mother and my sister must be banish'd to a distance.—Why, this Jew, this usurer, this enemy to our faith, whose heart is in his bags, wou'd not have us'd me thus—I'll question him—Sheva!

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: What is your pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I do not know the word.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: What is your will then? speak it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Sheva!—You have been a son—you had a mother—dost remember her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Goot lack, goot lack! do I remember her!—

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Did'st love her, cherish her, support her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Ahme! ah me! It is as much as my poor heart will bear to think of her—I wou'd have died—

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Thou hast affections, feelings, charities—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I am a man, sir, call me how you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I'll call you Christian then, and this proud merchant Jew.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I shall not thank you sor that compli∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: And had'st thou not a sister too?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: No, no sister, no broder, no son, no daughter: I am a solitary being, a waif on the world's wide common.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: And thou hast hoarded wealth, till thou art sick with gold even to plethory: thy bags run over with the spoils of usury; thy veins are glutted with the blood of prodigals and gamesters.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I have enough: something perhaps to spare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: And I have nothing, nothing to spare but miseries, with which my measure overflows—by Heaven, it racks my soul, to think that those beloved sufferers should want, and this thing so abound [aside.]—Now, Sheva, now, if you and I were out of sight of man, benighted in some desart, wild as my thoughts, naked as my fortune, shou'd you not tremble?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: What shou'd I tremble for?—You cou'd not harm a poor defenceless aged man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Indeed, indeed I cou'd not harm you, Sheva, whilst I retain'd my senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Sorrow disturbs them; yes, yes, it is sorrow. Ah me, ah me! poor Sheva in his time has been driven mad with sorrow.—'Tis a hard world.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Sir, I have done you wrong—You pity me, I'm sure you do: those tones cou'd never proceed but from a feeling heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Try me, touch me; I am not made of marble.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: No, on my life you are not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
Nor yet of gold extorted from the prodigal: I am no shark to prey upon mankind. What I
have got, I have got by little and little, working hard and pinching my own bowels—I cou'd say something, it is in my thoughts; but no, I will not say it here: this is the house of trade; that is not to my purpose—Come home with me, so please you—'Tis but a little walk, and you shall see what I have shewn to no man, Sheva's real heart—I do not carry it in my hand—Come, come, I pray you come along.

SP.SPEAKER: ELIZA.
SP.P: OH! happy me, possess'd of all my heart de∣lights in; and miserable me, for having ruin'd what I love. Alas! poor Bertram, fond to despe∣ration, generous to thy destruction!—Why then did I marry, wherefore did I suffer him to be the vic∣tim of a fatal passion? What power perverted un∣derstanding, heart, humanity? What power but that, which can do all things, good or ill, make virtue and unmake it, animate our courage and ex∣tinguish it?—Love is at once my crime and my excuse. Good heavens! my mother.—
SP.STAGE: [ELIZA takes her hand and kisses it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Eliza! Child! what means this more than usual agitation?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Is it then more than usual?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: You weep—

SP.SPEAKER: Eliz.
SP.P: Do I? 'Tis natural, when I contemplate face so dear and so decay'd, furrow'd with cares and sorrows for my sake.—Ah! my dear mother, you have lov'd me much too well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: My darling, can that be, seeing I love your brother also? You share my heart between you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Give all to him: he has deserv'd it better.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Heaven bless him to the extent of his deservings! On him rests all our hope; to him we cling, as to the last dear relick of our wreck'd nobility. But he's a man, Eliza, and endow'd with strength and fortitude to struggle in the storm; we are weak helpless women, and can do no more than suffer and submit.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: True, but there is a part allotted to the weakest, even to me; an humble one indeed, and easily perform'd, since nothing is requir'd but to obey, to love you and to honour you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: And you have done it faithfully, my child.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You think so, my dear mother, but your praise is my reproach.—Oh! had I now a crime upon my conscience, and shou'd I kneel thus and beg for pardon at your feet, what wou'd you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Astonishment might keep me silent for a while, but my first words wou'd be to pity and forgive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: That I can err this guilty hand will wit∣ness.—Well may you start. That hand is Ber∣tram's; and that ring, pledg'd at the altar, was put on by him this very morning—I am Bertram's wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Rise, quit this supplicating posture till you find yourself in presence of some person less dispos'd to pardon you than I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: How mild is that rebuke! how merciful! Your eye, like Nature's, penetrates my heart: you see it weak as woman's resolution is, empassion'd not impure, conquer'd but not corrupted.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: I see myself reflected in my child: jus∣tice demands a censure; conscious recollection checks me from pronouncing it: but you have a brother, whose high-soaring spirit will not brook clandestine marriages: your husband has a father of another spirit as I fear. Alas! my child, be∣twixt the lofty and the low you must steer well to keep a steady course.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I see my danger; and tho' Bertram's ar∣dor painted it in fainter colours than it's true com∣plexion may demand, yet I shou'd hope the nature of a father cannot be so stern as never to forgive a choice that disappoints, but, let me hope, does not disgrace him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: The name of Ratcliffe cannot. A daughter of your house in better days wou'd hardly have advanc'd his knighthood higher than her foot-cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Aye, Madam, but the pride of birth does but add stings to poverty. We must forget those days.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Your father did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Ah, my father!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Your brother never will.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
Yet he is humble for our sakes. Think what he does. Good heavens, my husband's father's clerk. Dear Madam, tell me why he did not rather go where his courage call'd him, where his
person wou'd have grac'd the colors that he carried.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Child, child, what colors? Surely you forget the interdiction of a father barr'd him from that service.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Alas, alas!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: The bread wou'd choak him, that he earn'd under a father's curse.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: We have bled for our opinions, and we have starv'd for them: the axe and sword and po∣verty have made sad havoc with our family: 'tis time we were at peace. The world is now before us: on this hour depends the fate of all perhaps that are to come. Frederic is with his father; he is determin'd to avow his marriage, and to meet the consequences. I never saw Sir Stephen, and have nothing but conjecture to direct me: I tremble for the event.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: 'Tis a distressful interim; and it is now the hour when I expect your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Oh! that is worse than all; for pity's sake hide me from him till Frederic returns: let me retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Come then, my child! I know not what it is, but something whispers me that all will yet be well.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Ten thousand blessings on you for that chearing hope: how my heart bounds to embrace it! 'Tis an auspicious omen, and I hail it like the voice of inspiration.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Why Jabal, I say Jabal! Where are you, sluggard?

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Here am I, mother Dorcas! Oh! what a starving star was I born under, to be the rich Jew's poor servant. No rest, no peace whilst you are awake. Lud-a-mercy! if you did but know how your pipe echoes in this empty house.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Child, child, you must not think to be idle here.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: What wou'd you have me do? Brush the bare walls for a breakfast? A spider could not make a meal upon them.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: I warrant thou hast fill'd thy belly, cor∣morant.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: I have not had a belly-full since I belong'd to you. You take care there shall be no fire in the kitchen, master provides no prog upon the shelf, so between you both I have plenty of nothing but cold and hunger.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Hunger indeed! How shou'd thy sto∣mach ever be fill'd, when there is no bottom to it? 'tis like the Dead Sea, fathomless.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: 'Tis like the Dead Sea so far, that neither fish nor flesh are to be found within it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Sirrah! you have a better master than you think for. It is unknown the charities he gives away.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P:
You're right, it is unknown; at least I
never found the secret out. If it is charity to keep an empty cupboard, he has that to boast of; the very rats wou'd run away from such a caterer. If it is charity to clothe the naked, here is a sample of it: examine this old drab, you may count the threads without spectacles; a spider's web is a warm blanket to it. If it is charity to feed the hungry, I have an empty stomach at his service, to which his charity at this present moment would be very seasonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: You must mortify your carnal appetities: how often shall I teach you that lesson?

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Every time I set eyes upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Hav'n't you the credit of belonging to one of the richest men in the city of London?

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: I wish I was turnspit to the poorest cook's shop instead. Oh! if my master had but fixt his abode at Pye Corner, or Pudding-lane, or Fish∣street-hill, or any of those savory places!—What am I the fatter for the empty dignity of Duke's Place? I had rather be a miser's heir than a miser's servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: And who knows what may happen? Master has not a relation I ever heard of in the universal world.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: No, he has starv'd 'em all out. A ca∣meleon cou'd not live with him; he wou'd grudge him even the air he feeds on.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: For shame, slanderer! His good deeds will shine out in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P:
I shan't stand in their light; they may shine through me, for I am grown transparent in
his service.—Had not he like to have been torn to pieces t'other day by the mob for whipping a starv'd cat out of his area?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: And whose fault was that but thine, un∣gracious boy, for putting it there? I am sure I have cause to bless the gentleman that sav'd him.—But hush! Here comes my good master; and as I live the very gentleman with him—Ah! then I guess what is going forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: So, so, so! What's here to do with you? Why are you not both at your work?—Dorcas, a cup of cold water—I am very thirsty.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Are you not rather hungry too, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, puppy! Get about your business; and here! take my hat, clean it carefully, but mind you do not brush it—that will wear off the nap.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: The nap indeed! There is not shelter for a flea.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Aha! I am tired. I beg your pardon, Mr. Ratcliffe; I am an old man. Sit you down, I pray you, sit you down, and we will talk a little. [DORCAS brings a glass of water] So, so! that is right. Water is goot.—Fie upon you, Dorcas; why do you not offer the glass to my guest before me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Lord love him! I'd give him wine, if I had it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
No, no, it is goot water, it is better
than wine: wine is heating, water is cooling; wine costs monies, water comes for nothing—Your good health, Sir—Oh! 'tis delicious, it is satis∣fying: I was very empty before, my stomach was craving, now I am quite content.—Go your ways, Dorcas, go your ways.—(Exit DORCAS.) Sir, I have nothing to ask you to but that water, which you wou'd not drink: 'twas very goot water not∣withstanding.—Ah! Mr. Ratcliffe, I must be very saving now; I must pinch close.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: For what? Are you not rich enough to al∣low yourself the common comforts of life?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Oh yes, oh yes! I am rich to be sure—Mercy on me, what a world of monies shou'd I now have, if I had no pity in my heart! But it melts and melts, or else—Oh! dear me, what a heap it wou'd have been!

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir, if I say there are some seem∣ing contradictions in your character, which I can∣not reconcile. You give away your money, it should seem, with the generosity of a prince, and I hear you lament over it in the language of a miser.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: That is true, that is very true: I love my monies, I do love them dearly; but I love my fellow-creatures a little better.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Being so charitable to others, why then will you not spare a little to yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
Because I am angry with myself for being such a baby, a child, a chicken. Your people do not love me, what business have I to love your people? I am a Jew; my fathers up to Abraham
all were Jews—Merciless mankind, how you have persecuted them! My family is all gone, it is ex∣tinct, my very name will vanish out of memory when I am dead—I pray you pardon me; I'm very old, and apt to weep; I pray you pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I am more dispos'd to subscribe to your tears than to find fault with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Well, well, well! 'tis natural for me to weep when I reflect upon their sufferings and my own.—Sir, you shall know—but I won't tell you my sad story: you are young and tender-hearted—It is all written down—You shall find it with my papers at my death.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Sir!—At your death?—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Yes, sure, I must die some time or other: tho' you have sav'd my life once, you cannot save it always: I did tell you, Mr. Ratcliffe, I wou'd shew you my heart. Sir, it is a heart to do you all possible good whilst I live, and to pay you the debt of gratitude when I die: I believe it is the only one I owe to the pure benevolence of my fellow-creatures.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I am sorry you have found mankind so un∣grateful.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Not so, not so; I might perhaps have found them grateful, if I had let them know their benefactor; I did relieve their wants, but I did not court their thanks: they did eat my bread, and hooted at me for a miser.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P:
A gentleman, who says his name is Ber∣tram,
waits to speak with you—I fancy he comes to borrow money, for he looks wondrous melan∣choly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, knave; what is it to you what he comes for?

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: I'm sure he does not come for dinner, for he has not brought it with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I pray you, Mr. Ratcliffe, pass out that way, I wou'd not have you meet.—Admit Mr. Bertram.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: You are welcome, Mr. Bertram: our business may quickly be dispatch'd. You want three hundred pounds—I have made shift to scrape that sum together, and it is ready for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Alas, Sheva! since last I saw you I am so totally undone, that it wou'd now be robbery to take your money.—My father has expell'd me from his house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Why? for what cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I have married—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Well, that is natural enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Married without his knowledge—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: So did he without your's. What besides?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Married a wife without a farthing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Ah! that is very silly, I must say.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: You cou'd not say so, did you know the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: That may be, but I do not know the lady: you have not nam'd her to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: The sister of Charles Ratcliffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Ah! to Miss Rateliffe? Is it so? And she is goot and lovely, but she has no monies; and that has made your fader very angry with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Furious, irreconcileable.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Why truly, monies is a good thing, and your fader is not the only man in England that does think so: I confess I'm very much of his mind in respect of monies.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I know you are; therefore keep your money, and good morning to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Hold, hold, be not so hasty! If I do love my monies, it may be because I have it in my power to tender them to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: But I have said I never can repay you whilst you are in this world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Perhaps I shall be content to be repaid when I am out of it—I believe I have a pretty many post-obits of that sort upon the file.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I do not rightly understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Then pray you have a little patience till I'm better understood.—Sir Stephen had a match for you in view?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: He had.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: What was the lady's fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Ten thousand pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: That is a goot round sum; but you did not love her, and you do love your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: As dearly as you love your money.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
A little better we will hope, for I do lend my monies to my friend.—For instance, take these bills, three hundred pounds—What ails you?—They are goot bills, they are bank—Oh! that
I had a sack full of them!—Come, come, I pray you take them. They will hire you very pretty lodging, and you will be very happy with your pretty wife—I pray you take them.—Why will you be so hard with a poor Jew as to refuse him a goot bargain, when you know he loves to lay his monies out to profit and advantage?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Are you in earnest? You astonish me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I am a little astonish'd too, for I did never see a man so backward to take money: you are not like your fader. I am afraid you are a little proud.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: You shall not say so: I accept your ge∣nerous tender.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I wish it was ten thousand pounds, then your goot fader wou'd be well content.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Yes, of two equal fortunes I believe he wou'd be good enough to let me take my choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Oh! that is very kind; he wou'd give you the preference when he had none himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Just so: but what acknowledgment shall I give you for these bills?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: None, none; I do acknowledge them myself with very great pleasures in serving you, and no small pains in parting from them. I pray you, make yourself and pretty wife comfortable with the monies, and I will comfort myself as well as I can without them—Ah, poor Sheva! when thou art beggar man, who will take pity of thee?—Well, well! no matter—now I must take a little walk about my business—I pray you pardon my unpoliteness.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: No apology: I am gone—Farewell, Sheva! Thou a miser! thou art a prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Jabal! open the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: 'Tis done, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: How now, Sirrah! You was listening at the key-hole.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Not I, Sir; I was only oiling the lock: You love to have your bolts slip easily.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: You are a jackanapes: I shall slip you out of my door by and bye.

SP.SPEAKER: JABAL.
SP.P: You may slip me thro' the crack of it, if I stay much longer with you—But to be sure I did listen, that is the truth of it. Hip! Holloa! Mother Dorcas!

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Oh! I am glad you are in the way. Lend me your one ear, and I'll tell you a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Let us hear it, Jabal, I love a secret—Come on this side of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: That's true; your left ear—Well, do you hear me? I have made a discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: I have no objection to a discovery. Out with it!

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Mother Dorcas, I have discover'd that our old master is no more a miser than I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: I told you so.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P:
So you did, but that's not all. I have found out besides that he is no Hebrew, no more a Jew than Julius Caesar; for to my certain knowledge
he gives away his money by handfulls to the con∣sumers of hogs-flesh.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: He is merciful to all mankind.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Yes, and to all sheep and oxen, lambs and calves, for he will not suffer us to touch a morsel of their flesh. Now because he lives without food, that's no reason I shou'd starve for want of eating. Oh! Mother Dorcas, 'tis untold what terrible and abominable temptations I struggle with.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: How are you tempted, child? Tell me what it is that moves you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Why 'tis the devil himself, in the shape of a Bologna sausage: Gracious! how my mouth did water, as I saw a string of them dangling from the penthouse of an oilman's shop! The fellow wou'd have persuaded me they were made of ass's flesh—Oh! if I cou'd have believ'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Oh! horrible! You must not touch the unclean beast.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: No, to be sure; our people have never tasted bacon since they came out of the land of Ham.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Jabal, Jabal, what an escape you have had!

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: So had the sausages, for my teeth quiver'd to be at them.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Come, my good lad, thou shalt be re∣compens'd for thy self-denial: I have an egg for thee in the kitchen.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P:
I hope it is an ostrich's, for I am mortally sharp set—Oh, mother, I have a thought in my
head—I will give old master warning, and seek my fortune elsewhere.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Where will you seek it?

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Where there is plenty of prog, be assur'd—I will go upon the stage and turn actor: there is a great many eating parts, and I hope to fill them all. I spent sixpence t'other night upon a farce, where there was a notable fine leg of lamb serv'd up before the audience. Oh how I did long to be the attorney! I won't say so many good things wou'd have come out of my mouth, but a pretty many more wou'd have gone into it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: How you ramble, Sirrah! What me∣grims you have in your head!

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Emptiness breeds them. Mercy, how glad I should be to see it written down in my part—
SP.STAGE: Enter Jabal with a roast chicken!

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Come, come, homelier fare must con∣tent you. Let us light the lamp, and boil our egg.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: What! is it between us? One egg, and two to eat it?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Well, I care not if I spend sixpence for a treat, so thou wilt be sociable and merry when it is over.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Agreed! only give me good cheer for my dinner, and we will have good humour for the desert.

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERIC.
SP.P: CAN you forgive me? Has my lovely ad∣vocate sued out my pardon, and may I now invoke a blessing on my love and me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Heaven in its bounty bless you both! May all good fortune follow you, all comforts light upon you, and love and happiness ever subsist be∣tween you!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Such piety can never pray in vain.—Where is Eliza?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: She does not know you are here. Shall I call her?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Not yet. I have a little sum, and you must be our banker: Charles is too proud to touch it; his spirit is of a pitch too high to stoop to worldly matters. We have been warm and cor∣dial friends, how we may fare as brothers, Heaven only knows: I have some fears.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Eliza is impressed with the same ap∣prehensions, but if Sir Stephen acquiesces; all will be well: I hope this money is a token of his for∣giveness.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: 'Twill serve to set us out: I have pro∣vided lodgings more commodious; I hope you will permit Eliza to remove, and I make further suit that you will have the goodness to accompany her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Well; but you do not answer to my question of the money.—Hav'n't you seen your father?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I have seen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: And explain'd to him—?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Well! what says he?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: If he had said what wou'd have done him honor, and given ease to my Eliza's mother, I should not have waited for your question: But nature must have time to work. I have only stirr'd the dregs.—May I now see Eliza? There is a cloud on my heart also, which only her bright pre∣sence can dispel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Ah! Sir, she can be only bright hence∣forward by reflection; her sunshine must be caught from your's.—However, I will send her to you.

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERIC.
SP.P: Oh! that my father was now standing by me to behold her, and confess how irresistible she is!—
Oh! my soul's joy, my treasure, my Eliza!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Frederic, what tidings?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P:
None but of love, encreasing with each moment, glowing with every beam that those soft
eyes diffuse, and heighten'd into rapture by those charms, those graces, that each look, word, mo∣tion spread around you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: These are fond flattering words; but where's the consolation, that you wou'd have given me had you brought back a pardon from your father? This ardor only proves that you had too much love, and I too little generosity.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Take courage, Eliza! I have not lost the field, only prolong'd the fight: I have but skir∣mish'd with him yet; he has not felt my strength. Let me set you in sight, and if there is a callous in his heart, (which I won't say there is) your eyes, my charmer, will refine and melt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: My eyes have injur'd him too much al∣ready.—Oh! you rash man, why did you take such pains to be undone? Why lull me into dreams of happiness, till I forgot that I was poor and wretch∣ed? Deceiver of yourself and me, I thought we trode on flowers, and never spied the precipice be∣hind you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I see no precipice; I fear none.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
Hear me, my Frederic, let love stand off a while, and give your ear to reason.—'Tis fit that you should know the heart, for which you have risqu'd so much. Our marriage was a rash one; be that my witness how I lov'd you, for never till this day had I the recollection of one act, that weigh'd upon my conscience, or reproach'd me with the sin of disobedience in the slightest instance: But, though I wanted firmness to oppose your love, I am not void of courage to prevent your ruin.—
Have patience! hear me out—Sir Stephen Ber∣tram wish'd for money; I have none to give him, the fortune of my house is crush'd, the spirit yet survives, even in me, the weakest and perhaps the humblest of the name; but I resist contempt, and, if he spurns my poverty, I have a sure resource, that shall compel him to applaud my spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: What do you mean? Your looks, your language terrify me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Oh! I have lov'd you far too well to trifle. I will convince the world 'twas not by in∣terest my heart was gain'd; 'twas not to keep off want, to live at ease, and make the noble relicks of my family retainers of his charity, I married to Sir Stephen Bertram's son; it was with worthier, purer views, to share his thoughts, unite my heart to his, and make his happiness my own: These sentiments are my inheritance; if these will not suffice for his ambition, they will teach me how to act becoming of my birth, under the imputation of his son's se∣ducer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Hence with that word! It is a profanation to your lips. Was ever man so blest, so honor'd, so exalted as I am? If pride will not see it, if avarice cannot feel it, is that a reason why humility and gratitude shou'd not be blest in the enjoyment of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Eliza, your brother is come.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
Leave me, I beseech you, Frederic, leave
me! Let me confer with him alone: There's no way else to pacify him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Come, let us yield to her request: I do believe she's right.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Alone! how is my dear Eliza? You look pale, my love—Have you been out, or are you going out? Has any thing occurr'd? You are more drest than usual.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Am I? No, sure; you have seen this dress before. I have nothing new.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I can't say quite as much, for I have a new livelihood to seek: Sir Stephen has discarded me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Oh! fie upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: No, no; the man is worldly wise, no more. He has a son, Eliza, and he has found out I have a sister. Who can blame him? Beauty is a danger∣ous thing when honor does not guard it. But I know what my Eliza is, and therefore, to confute suspicion, and put this careful merchant at his ease, we will cut short the question, and retire from London.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Where must we go?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Far enough off for his repose be sure. I am sorry on account of Frederic, for I love him; but he has been too frequent in his visits here, and he knows I think so. He will be happier for our parting.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I doubt that—Is your resolution taken?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P:
Irrevocable—Northward is my point—
Where is my mother? I wou'd speak with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Stay! hear your sister first.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: What ails you? what is coming? Why do you tremble?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Oh, Charles!

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: What is it? Speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I am the wife of Frederic.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Heaven and good angels forbid it!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Heaven and good angels, as I hope, have witness'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Rash girl, you have undone him; torn asun∣der nature's strongest tye, set father against son—When was the name of Ratcliffe dishonor'd until now?—I've done with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Charles!—Brother!—Benefactor! Is there yet a name more tender, an appeal more sacred? Did hard fortune leave me only one protector, one dear friend, and will not he forgive me?—Take me then, and hurl me to the ground, as one not worth preserving.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Wretched Eliza, did I ever till this mo∣ment meet your embrace with coldness? Have I not lov'd you, heaven and earth, how much!—How then have I deserv'd to be dishonor'd by you, and to have my name stamp'd as the joint se∣ducer of a fond weak youth, who will have cause to execrate the hour when first he called me friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
Strike me not to the heart with your re∣proaches, but in pity hear me: I am not lightly-minded, not ignobly taught how to distinguish ho∣nor, for I am your sister, and have a saint, that does
not blush to call me daughter: She has pronounc'd my pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: She is all pity; sorrow has melted her fond heart to weakness.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: And can you then find no excuse for mine? What have I known but sorrow, except gratitude to you, and love to Frederic? Cannot you allow for a fond sorrow-melted heart in me as well as in my mother? You said but now that as a friend you lov'd him: I love him as a friend; but woman's friendship to your sex, when years, affections, sen∣timents so harmonize, as Frederic's with mine, how long will it retain its station in two hearts before it draws them closer, and unites them as you see?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: We'll have no more of this, Eliza. There is a weakness lurking at my heart, that warns me how I trust myself too far; you have made wreck of your own honor, wretched girl; I may still rescue mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. RATCLIFFE.
SP.P: Eliza!—my dear child! how has it pass'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: It is too plain how it has pass'd—She is in tears, pale and trembling—By my soul, it is too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Hush, hush! be still.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: She'll faint; by Heavens, she'll faint.—Oh, monstrous cruelty! Why did I leave her? Why did you persuade me?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Give me your arm—Lead me into the other room: I shall recover there, if you will be but patient.
SP.STAGE: (Scene changes to Sir STEPHEN BERTRAM's House.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir STEPHEN.
SP.P: Well, Saunders, what news have you been able to collect of my undutiful son?

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: I have not seen Mr. Bertram, but I am told he has settled himself in very handsome lodg∣ings, and is gone to remove his lady to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: His lady, do you call her? Can you find no fitter term? Where shou'd he get the means to settle? He was not furnish'd with them by me; who else will do it? If he attempts to raise money upon expectancies, be it at their peril, who are fools enough to trust him: No prudent man will be his bubble.—If I were sure that was his practice, I shou'd hold it matter of conscience to advertise against his debts.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: Perhaps there may be some persons in the world, who think you will not always hold out against an only son.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P:
Then let those persons smart for their opinion: they little know the feelings of an injur'd father; they cannot calculate my hopes, my disap∣pointments, my regret. He might have had a lady with an ample fortune: A wise without a shilling
is—but what avails complaint? Cou'd you learn nothing further who supplies him, who holds him up?

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: I hear that he had money of your broker, Sheva.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: That must be false intelligence. He will as soon make gold by transmutation, as wring it from the gripe of that old usurer: No, no, Sheva is too wary, too much a Jew to help him with a shilling.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: Yet I was so inform'd by his own servant Jabal. He says, Mr. Bertram came to old Sheva's house by appointment; that he overheard their whole conversation, in which your son very honorably stated the utter ruin your displeasure had brought upon him, and wou'd have refus'd the money, but that old Sheva forc'd it upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: It mocks all belief; it only proves that Sheva, the most inveterate miser in existence, has a fellow Jew for his servant, one of the com∣pletest liars in creation.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: I am apt to give him credit for the fact, notwithstanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Then give me leave to say you have more faith than most men living: was I to give so much credit, Mr. Saunders, I shou'd soon stop.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: I am not quite so fixt in my persuasion of old Sheva's character as you are. In his dealings, all the world knows he is punctiliously honest; no man's character stands higher in the Alley; and his servant tells me, though he starves himself, he is secretly very charitable to others.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Yes, this you may believe, if you are dis∣posed to take one Jew's word for another Jew's character: I am obstinate against both; and if he has supplied the money, as I am sure it must be on usurious principles, as soon as ever I have the old miser in my reach I will wring either the truth from his lips, or the life out of his carcase.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: How does my worthy master? I am your very humble servant, goot Sir Stephen Ber∣tram. I have a little private business to impart to you with your goot leave, and if your leisure serves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Leave us, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Aha! I am very much fatigued: there is great throng and press in the offices at the Bank, and I am aged and feeble.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Hold, Sir!—Before I welcome you within these doors, or suffer you to sit down in my pre∣sence, I demand to know explicitly, and without prevarication, if you have furnish'd my son with money secretly, and without my leave?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: If I do lend, ought I not to lend in se∣cret? If I do not ask your leave, Sir Stephen, may I not dispose of my own monies according to my own liking? But if it is a crime, I do wish to ask you who is my accuser? that, I believe, is justice every where, and in your happy country I do think it is law likewise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Very well, Sir, you shall have both law and justice. The information comes from your own servant Jabal. Can you controvert it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I do presume to say my servant ought not to report his master's secrets; but I will not say he has not spoken the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Then you confess the fact—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I humbly think there is no call for that: you have the information from my foot-boy—I do not deny it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: And the sum—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I do not talk of the sum, Sir Stephen, that is not my practice; neither, under favor, is my foot-boy my cashier. If he be a knave, and listen at my key-hole, the more shame his: I am not in the fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Not in the fault! Wretch, miser, usurer! you never yet let loose a single guinea from your gripe, but with a view of doubling it at the return. I know you what you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Indeed! 'tis more than I will say of my∣self.—I pray you, goot Sir Stephen, take a little time to know my heart, before you rob me of my reputation. I am a Jew, a poor defenceless Jew; that is enough to make me miser, usurer—Alas! I cannot help it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: No matter: you are caught in your own trap: I tell you now my son is ruin'd, disinherited, undone. One consolation is that you have lost your money.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
If that be a consolation, you are very
welcome to it. If my monies are lost, my motives are not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: I'll never pay one farthing of his debts; he has offended me for life; refus'd a lady with ten thousand pounds, and married a poor miss without a doit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Yes, I do understand your son is mar∣ried.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Do you so? By the same token I under▪ you to be a villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Aha! that is a very bad word—villain. I did never think to hear that word from one, who says he knows me. I pray you now permit me to speak to you a word or two in my own defence. I have done great deal of business for you, Sir Stephen; have put a pretty deal of monies in your pocket by my pains and labors: I did never wrong you of one sixpence in my life: I was content with my lawful commission.—How can I be a villain?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Do you not uphold the son against the fa∣ther?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I do uphold the son, but not against the fader; it is not natural to suppose the oppressor and the fader one and the same person. I did see your son struck down to the ground with sorrow, cut to the heart: I did not stop to ask whose hand had laid him low; I gave him mine, and rais'd him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: You! you to talk of charity!

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I do not talk of it; I feel it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: What claim have you to generosity, hu∣manity, or any manly virtue? Which of your mo∣ney-making tribe ever had sense of pity? Shew me the terms, on which you have lent this money, if you dare! Exhibit the dark deed, by which you have mesh'd your victim in the snares of usury; but be assured I'll drag you to the light, and pub∣lish your base dealings to the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Take your hand from my coat—my coat and I are very old, and pretty well worn out together—There, there! be patient—moderate your passions, and you shall see my terms; they are in little compass: fair dealings may be com∣prised in few words.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: If they are fair, produce them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Let me see, let me see!—Ah, poor Sheva!—I do so tremble, I can hardly hold my pa∣pers—So, so! Now I am right—Aha! here it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Let me see it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Take it—Do you not see it now? Have you cast your eye over it? Is it not right? I am no more than broker, look you: If there is a mistake, point it out, and I will correct it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Ten thousand pounds invested in the the three per cents. money of Eliza, late Rat∣cliffe, now Bertram!

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Even so! a pretty tolerable fortune for a poor disinherited son not worth one penny.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: I'm thunderstruck!

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
Are you so? I was struck too, but not
by thunder. And what has Sheva done to be call'd villain?—I am a Jew, what then? Is that a reason none of my tribe shou'd have a sense of pity? You have no great deal of pity yourself, but I do know many many noble British mer∣chants that abound in pity, therefore I do not abuse your tribe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: I am confounded and asham'd; I see my fault, and most sincerely ask your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Goot lack, goot lack! that is too much, I pray you, goot Sir Stephen, say no more; you'll bring the blush upon my cheek, if you demean yourself so far to a poor Jew, who is your very humble servant to command.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Did my son know Miss Ratcliffe had this fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: When ladies are so handsome, and so goot, no generous man will ask about their for∣tune.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: 'Tis plain I was not that generous man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: No, no, you did ask about nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: But how, in the name of wonder, did she come by it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: If you did give me money to buy stock, wou'd you not be much offended were I to ask you how you came by it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Her brother was my clerk. I did not think he had a shilling in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
And yet you turn'd him upon the world, where he has found a great many shillings: The world, you see, was the better master of the two. Well, Sir Stephen, I will humbly take my leave.
You wish'd your son to marry a lady with ten thousand pounds, he has exactly fulfill'd your wishes; I do presume you will not think it neces∣sary to turn him out of doors, and disinherit him for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Go on, I merit your reproof. I shall henceforward be asham'd to look you or my son in the face.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: To look me in the face is to see nothing of my heart; to look upon your son, and not to love him, I shou'd have thought had been impos∣sible.—Sir Stephen, I am your very humble ser∣vant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Farewell, friend Sheva!—Can you forgive me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I can forgive my enemy; much more my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir STEPHEN.
SP.P: I AM wrong, Saunders, totally wrong in the manner I have resented my son's marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: I am happy to hear you say so. I flat∣ter'd myself you wou'd not hold out long against a worthy son: It is not in the nature of a father to resent so deeply.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Very true, Saunders, very true; my heart is not a hard one—but the lady he has married has ten thousand pounds to her fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: Oh! that indeed makes all the differ∣ence in life. That is a mollifying circumstance, I confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: I know not how she came by it. It seems to be the work of magic; but so it surely is; I saw the stock in Sheva's hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: Well, Sir, you cou'd not have it from better hands than from the author himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P:
How! What, from Sheva? Impossible! Ratcliffe is of a great family—Some sudden wind∣fall,
some relation dead. You'll see him in mourn∣ing next time you meet.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: He has not put it on yet, for I left him this minute in the counting-house: he is waiting to speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: So, so, so! Now then the news will come out—But pr'ythee don't let the gentleman wait. We must make up for past slights by double civility. Pray inform Mr. Ratcliffe I shall be most happy to receive his commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: O money, money! What a qualifier thou art!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir STEPHEN.
SP.P: Now I shall be curious to see how this young man will carry himself in prosperity. Had I but stayed one day longer without discharging him, I cou'd have met him with a better face.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Sir Stephen Bertram, I shall not engross much of your time. My business will be dispatch'd in a very few words.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Whatever commands you may have for me, Mr. Ratcliffe, I am perfectly at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I don't doubt it, Sir, but I shall not put your spirit to any great trial. My explanation will not be a hostile one, unless you chuse to understand it as such.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Far be it from me to wish it: Good terms between near connections, you know, Sir, should always be cultivated.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: You are pleas'd to be facetious, but your irony will not put me by from telling you that your son's connection with my family is no match of my making. If my sister has dishonor'd herself, it behoves me to say, and to say it on my solemn word, that the whole transaction was kept perfectly secret from me, and has receiv'd every mark of my displeasure and resentment, that I have as yet had an opportunity to give it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Proud as Lucifer himself! [aside.]—Well, Sir, if you are dissatisfied with the match, I can only say, I am not in the fault of it: but when you say your sister is dishonor'd, I protest I do not perfectly understand you; nor did I quite expect such an expression from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Probably you did not; your studies perhaps have laid more in the book of accompts than in the book of honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: You are very high, Sir; I am afraid your unexpected good fortune has rather intoxicated you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: No, Sir; the best good fortune I have known this day, was that which discharg'd me from your connection, not this, which unwillingly imposes it upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Very well, Mr. Ratcliffe! It was not with this sort of conversation I was prepar'd to en∣tertain you; the sooner we put an end to it the better: Only this I must take leave to tell you, that the fortune of the family, into which your sister has married, is by no means overbalanc'd by the fortune she has brought into it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Aye, now your heart's come out: that mer∣cenary taunt is all you have to say. But had my wish prevail'd, you never shou'd have had it in your power to utter Ratcliffe's name without a blush for your unwarranted suspicion of his honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir STEPHEN.
SP.P: He's mad; his head is turn'd: Prosperity has overset him. If the sister of the same blood is provided with no better brains, poor Frederic has made a precious bargain. We shall breed candi∣dates for Bedlam.

SP.SPEAKER: SHEVA
SP.P: Aha! very goot, very goot! I am at home. Now I will sit down in mine own parlour, and not ask leave of any body—I did not think I cou'd have given so large a sum away, and yet outliv'd it, but I am pretty well—There is but one man in the world poorer than he was, and he is going out of it; and there is a couple at least a great deal happier, and they are coming into it. Well, well! that is two for one, cent. per cent. so I have made pretty goot bargain.—Now I will ring my bell and order my dinner: Yes, yes, I will eat my dinner, for I am hungry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
Oh! you knave! Oh you picklock! how dare you listen at my door and hear my secrets?
Sirrah, I will have your ears nail'd to it.—Don't you speak, don't you speak; you will make me angry, and that will spoil my appetite.—What have you got in the house sor my repast?

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Plenty, as good luck will have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Plenty, say you? What is it? Let me hear.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: One egg-shell, and the skins of three po∣tatoes: shall I serve them up at once, or make two courses of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: How now, you jack-an-apes! One egg-shell is nothing goot for a hungry man. Have you left some of the potatoes in the skins?

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Not an atom; you may have the broth they were boil'd in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: You are a saucy knave, to make a joke of your master. Do you think I will keep a jack-pudding in my house like you, to listen at my key∣hole, and betray my conversation? Why did you say I gave away my monies.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: What harm did I do? Nobody believ'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Go your ways, go your ways; you are not for my purpose, you are not fit to be trusted; you do let your idle tongue run away with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: That is because you won't employ my teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: You do prate too much; you do chatter, and bring your poor master into great straits: I have been much mal-treated and abus'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Have you so? I wish to goodness I had been by.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Sirrah! you wish you had been by, to hear your master abus'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Yes, for I wou'd have dealt the fellow that abus'd you such a recompence in the fifth button, that my friend Mendoza should not have plac'd it better.—Damn it! do you think I wou'd stand by and hear my master abus'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Don't you swear, don't you swear—That is goot lad, but don't you swear.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: No, by the living! tho' I may be starv'd in your service, I will die in your defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Well, well, you are a merry knave—but my eyes do water a little; the air is sharp, and they are weak. Go your ways, go your ways—Send Dorcas to me.

I cannot tell what ails my heart all this day long, it is so troublesome. I have spent ten thousand pounds to make it quiet, but there must be a little fraction more—I must give the poor knave some∣thing for his good will—Oh dear, oh dear! What will become of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: So, so! Come hither, Dorcas. Why do you look sad? What ails you, girl? Why do you cry?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Because you are going to turn away Jabal: He is the kindliest, willingest, good na∣tur'dest soul alive—The house will be a dungeon without Jabal.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
Then tell him 'tis at your request I let
him stay in his dungeon. Say, that I was very angry with him, but that you pacified my anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Lord love your heart! that is so like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Hark you, Dorcas, I will give you this piece of money to make the poor knave merry; but mind that you bestow it on him as your own little present, and promise not to say it comes from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: Well, to be sure you do not give your money like other people. If ever I do a good turn, I take care the person I favor shou'd know from whence it comes, that so he may have the pleasure of returning it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Well, Dorcas, you take your course, and I take mine—Now I will go and beg a bit of din∣ner of a friend. You are a very goot house-wife, Dorcas; you do keep an empty kitchen and a clean cupboard.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorcas.
SP.P: And whose fault is that? How many people are feasting abroad at your cost, whilst you have a famine at home? But here comes your friend and neighbour Mrs. Goodison; she will take care of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Ah! my good sir, I perceive you are at your old sport; no smoke in your chimney, no cloth upon your table, full coffers and an empty cupboard.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: No, no, my coffers are not full, I am very poor just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Come then, and partake with one, whom your bounty has made rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Do not talk of my bounty; I do never give away for bounty's sake; if pity wrings it from my heart, whether I will or not, then I do give: How can I help it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Well, sir, I can be silent, but I cannot forget—And now if you will come and share my grateful meal, perhaps I can shew you one of the loveliest objects in creation, a beautiful and amiable young bride, who with her husband and mother is now my lodger. She was married this very morn∣ing to your friend Sir Stephen Bertram's son, who, between you and me, has brought himself into sad trouble with his father by the match. But surely if there is a woman upon earth worth a man's being ruin'd for, it must be this young creature—So modest, so sweet-temper'd, so engaging—Oh! that Sir Stephen had your heart!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: It might be inconvenient to him, if he had: It is not kept for nothing, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: You wou'd not turn such a daughter-in-law from your doors—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Nor will he, perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P:
Ah! sir, I know a little better: The poor young gentleman himself told me he was ruin'd: “But don't be afraid to take me into your house,” added he, with a sigh that went to my heart; “I am provided with the means of doing justice to you by a generous friend,” shewing me a bank bill of one hundred pounds—Heaven bless that gener∣ous friend! quoth I—and at that moment I thought
of you; my good Mr. Sheva, who rescued me from the like distress, when my poor husband died.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: You may think of me, Mrs. Goodison; but I must beg you will not speak of me in the hearing of your lodgers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Well, well, sir, if I must not speak, I must not; yet a strange thing came out in conversa∣tion with the mother of the bride, a very excellent lady, from whom I found out that she is the widow of that very gentleman we knew at Cadiz by the name of Don Carlos only, and to whom I believe you think yourself under some obligations in your escape from that country.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Mercies upon his heart! he was the pre∣server of my life; but for his charitable succour, this poor body wou'd have fed the fires of an Auto da fé. Is it possible Mrs. Ratcliffe is the widow of my benefactor?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Most certain that she is, which you may soon be convinc'd of; but I perceive you know the lady's name.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Did you not name the lady yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: No, on my word. Ah, sir, you are fairly caught; you have betrayed yourself: Ill deeds, they say, will come to light, and so will good ones, it shou'd seem.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, hold your tongue; you forget that I am fasting and without a dinner; go your ways, and I will follow: You are nimble, I am slow; you will be sham'd with your lodgers, if they see you with a poor old Jew like me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P:
Ah! You are cunning in your
charities; but I'll do as you wou'd have me, and be ready at the door to receive and welcome you.

SP.SPEAKER: SHEVA
SP.P: —The widow of my preserver from the inquisitors of Cadiz, and the mother of my rescuer from the mob of London!—Dear me, dear me! How Providence disposes all things!—The friend that's dead wants nothing; the friend that is alive shall likewise want nothing that I can give him; for I will die quickly my own self, and give him all. Goot lack! goot lack! when I did heap up monies with such pains and labor, I did always think that I shou'd find an use for them at last,

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I have cleared myself to his father, and I'll clear myself to all the world. No man shall say I lay traps for heirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Charles, Charles, you soar too high.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Madam, madam, you stoop too low.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: How is your honor slighted, when your friend did not consult even his father?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: He knew his father's mind too well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: And what wou'd you have done?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I wou'd have sav'd my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: And sacrific'd your sister—That, let me say, is a high strain of friendship, but no great proof of brotherly affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P:
Sister, there is more peace of mind sa∣crific'd
by indulging in an act to be repented of, than by foregoing a dishonorable propensity. The woman without fortune, that consents to a clan∣destine marriage with a man, whose whole de∣pendance is upon an unforgiving father, never can be justified.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You argue from the unforgiving nature of Sir Stephen Bertram: You had experience of it, I have none.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: You might have had, by an appeal to his consent, before you gave your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: You bear too hard upon your sister. You forget her sex, her situation, your own tender∣ness and the affection you have ever borne her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: No, madam, if I cou'd forget how proudly I have thought of her, I shou'd not be so humbled by her conduct as I am. I own I stand in wonder and amaze at your indifference. You think I am too sensitive, too proud; you tell me that I soar too high. How was it when I was this Bertram's clerk? I bore my lot with patience, I submitted without murmuring to poverty: I cannot brook disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Well, Charles, if you cou'd love me only whilst you thought me faultless, I must wonder how it was that we were friends so long: And now you have said all that rigid justice can enforce against me; had you said less, I shou'd have felt it more.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P:
Charles—Brother—Friend!—Will you not give me joy? Come, man, shake off this cloud,
and smile upon my happiness; we catch it but by gleams.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch
SP.P: Yes, sir, we sometimes catch it by surprize and stealth; we catch it by a breach of promise and good faith—Then to congratulate a man on such a catch, in my sense of the word, wou'd be to libel him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I have frequently seen cause to applaud your philosophy, Charles: Now I must think you carry it too far.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: It touches you too near, therefore you like it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: To that remark I shou'd return an answer, were not these dear pledges present, that might a little ruffle your philosophy perhaps, but it wou'd fully vindicate my principle.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Postpone it then, but don't forget it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: When friends fall into altercation on such points as these, there shou'd be none to witness to their folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Folly!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Son, son, no more of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
Stop, I conjure you both!—Charles, Charles, if you have love or pity left, let this dis∣sension go no further. And you, Frederic—Hus∣band!—You whose generous heart has put to hazard every hope for me, add yet another proof of love, by suffering these rebukes with patience: They are but flashes of a temper, warm in friend∣ship, glowing with honor, impatient of neglect. Perhaps my brother thinks ambition, meanness, artifice, might hav some part, some influence, in
moving me to what I've done.—I spurn such motives, disavow them all—Were I in Frederic's place, and he in mine, I shou'd have done as he did; I shou'd have thought no sacrifice too great to have secur'd a lasting interest in a heart like his.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: This had been only ruin to yourself, and wou'd have had the plea of spirit, therefore more excuseable: but this no man of honor wou'd have suffer'd; therefore 'tis only said, not done.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Whatever my Eliza says is done; her actions verify her words, and he that doubts them wou'd dispute against the light of Heaven. 'Tis I that am advanc'd, she is abas'd; 'tis I that am enrich'd, Eliza is impoverish'd: I only risque a few sharp words from an ungentle father, she suffers keen reproaches undeserv'd from an injurious brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Urge me no further—I can bear no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Oh! my dear mother, save me!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: There, there! You've struck her to the heart—and that's a coward's blow—
SP.STAGE: [Apart to CHARLES, in an under voice.
SP.P: My life, my soul, look up! Dear madam, take her hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: A coward's blow!—You recollect those words, and know their meaning, I suppose—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Yes, and will meet your comment when you will and where you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Then follow me, and we'll adjust that matter speedily.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I will but but drop a tear upon the ruin you have made, and then be with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I'll wait for you below.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Where are you both, rash men? Ah Frederic! Alone!—What is become of Charles? Why is he gone away? What have you said to him? I did not hear it; I was lost in terror—I am sure you have quarrell'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: No, no, not quarrell'd—only jarr'd, as friends will sometimes do—all will be set to rights.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: How? When? Why not this moment, in my hearing? I shall be happy to make peace between you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Peace will be made, assure yourself, sweet love: These little heats are easily adjusted.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: But I cou'd do it best; you are too hot, both, both too hot and fiery.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: We shall be cooler soon; such heats soon spend themselves, and then the heart is laid to rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Heaven grant such rest to your's!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
What says my Frederic? You are still dis∣compos'd. Your color comes and goes—Oh! that my arms cou'd give you rest!—Nay, what now, my Frederic! You struggle to get loose—Are these soft toils uneasy to you? Will not your proud
swelling heart endure such gentle fond imprison∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Oh! thou angelic virtue, soul-dissolving softness, wou'd I might thus expire enfolded in these arms! Love, I conjure thee to bear up; I am sure my father will take pity and be kind to thee: I shall assail his feelings in a manner that no parent can resist. I am going now to put it to the proof.—Farewell!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Why in such haste?—Stay yet a little while—If you depart so soon, you'll meet with Charles again, and then—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Some fatal accident will be the issue of it, Alas! You know not what his passions are when once inflamed; let them burn out, and then he's calm as water.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Where does this tend? You wou'd not make a coward of your husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: No, nor wou'd you make a distracted wretch of your poor Eliza; therefore I will not let you loose till you have promis'd me not to pro∣voke him to more violence: Promise me this and you shall go.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Well then, if that will set your mind at rest, I promise you I'll have no further altercation with him, not another word to gall him.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You'll not renew your quarrel?—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
