SP.P: No, my Eliza, we will end it, and dismiss it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: And this you promise on your honor—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Yes, I do promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
Then all my fears are over—Now you
may go—Well! What withholds you? What more do you wish than freedom and release from my fond arms?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: To snatch one last dear moment, and then die within them—Oh! my soul's better part, may Heaven preserve and bless you!

SP.SPEAKER: ELIZA.
SP.P: Now I am happy, now I am secure; this breach once heal'd, I can face all alarms.

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERIC.
SP.P: IS the porter return'd, who went with my mes∣sage to Mr. Saunders, at Sir Stephen Ber∣tram's?

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: He is, sir; the gentleman will be with you presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Shew him up as soon as he comes—There will be another gentleman call; I believe you know Mr. Ratcliffe?

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Yes, we know Mr. Ratcliffe very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: If he comes whilst Mr. Saunders is with me, request him to wait a few minutes till he is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: I shall, sir—Any other commands?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: None.

I scarce know what I've written to my father; yet perhaps these few unstudied lines, dictated in such a moment, may dispose him to protect the widow, if fate will have it so, of a discarded son.—Now I am ready for this angry champion; and since he is resolv'd to vindicate his courage by his sword, let
him produce his weapons when he will, I'll not re∣fuse the satisfaction he demands.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, Sir! I'm overjoy'd to find you—Come, I pray you, come away to my old master, who is pining till he sees you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Who is your master, and who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: As if you did'nt know Jabal, who lives—No, hold there, who does not live, but starves with your old friend in Duke's Place. Why, lud-a-mercy, I knew your honor at the length of the street, and saw you turn into this tavern: the pup∣pily waiter wou'd have stopt me from coming up to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I wish you had taken his advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: That wou'd not be your wish if you knew all. Sure enough I must hunt up Mr. Rat∣cliffe also; for there is an iron in the fire for each of you: Master is making his will—Lawyer Dash is at his elbow.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: If the devil was at his elbow, I cannot come to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: Oh, the living! I wou'd not carry such a message back for all the world—Why, when Lawyer Dash has pen and ink in hand, and a will under his thumb, he'll dash you in or dash you out in a crack.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Then temper the apology to your taste, only let your master understand I cannot come.

SP.SPEAKER: Jabal.
SP.P: I'll tell him then you are married—That will be a silencer at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Begone! Make haste!—Married!—How cutting is that recollection! Joys just in fight, shewn only to be snatcht away. Dear, lost, undone Eliza!—But I won't think, for that is madness—Inexorable honor must be obey'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: Mr. Bertram, I came to you the first mo∣ment I cou'd get away; for I long'd to give you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Joy! name it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: Well, if your joy was somewhat damp'd at first, you may now take it without any draw∣back.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I know not what you mean, nor do I wish to enquire: be silent on that subject, I conjure you. The favor I have to ask of you is simply this—Here is a letter for my father; deliver it to him with your own hands—You seem surpriz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: I am indeed—the impatience of your looks—the hurry of your speech—the place in which I meet you—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: The letter will explain all that—I cou'd not give it you in presence of my—Well, no mat∣ter—I take you for a man of honor and my friend. Will you give the letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: Assuredly; but if I am a man of honor and your friend, why will you not let me stay with you? In truth, dear Frederick, I am a friend, that if you want him will not flinch.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P:
The friend I want, is one that will not
force his services upon me when I can't accept of them; but take my word at once, and leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: Enough! I am gone.

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERIC.
SP.P: I have been harsh with that good man, but this suspense is terrible.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Mr. Ratcliffe desires to know if you are at leisure.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Perfectly—Let him know I'm at his ser∣vice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I have brought my sword; compare it with your own, and if you have a preference, make your choice. I presume you have no objection to the weapon.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: None on my own account; a little per∣haps on the score of vanity, as thinking I have some advantage over you in point of skill and practice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: As far as that opinion goes, you're welcome to all the advantages it gives you. Oh! Sir, this is a sorry business—Will nothing else convince you I am incapable of giving a coward's blow?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: You have offer'd nothing else: it is a mode of your own chusing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Your language forc'd it on me: you have touch'd my feelings to the quick. Words, such as you made use of, cannot be pass'd over without ab∣solute disgrace, unless you will revoke them by apology.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: You may well conceive, Mr. Ratcliffe, with what repugnance I oppose myself to you on this occasion. Whether the event be fatal to you or to myself, small consolation will be left for the survivor. The course you take is warranted by every rule of honor, and you act no otherwise than as I expected: but as my expression justifies your challenge, so did your provocation justify my ex∣pression; and your language being addressed to a lady, whom I have the honor to protect, it is not in my power to retract one tittle of what I said; for, was you to repeat the same insult, I should fol∣low it with the same retort.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: If you hold to the words, I know not how we can adjust it amicably.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: There is a way: you must find it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Suppose, then, that my language had been addressed to any other person than Eliza, wou'd you in that case have apologiz'd for your expression?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I will speak plainly to you, and the rather as I am now perhaps speaking to you for the last time.—Admitted by your sister's favor into a family, whose representative resents her conduct, I will not so disgrace her choice in your eyes, who have op∣pos'd it, as to submit in the first instance to the most distant hint at an apology.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: I understand you now—You wou'd have it spring from me—Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Then no more is to be said.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: No more—Defend yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: What's that? I've wounded you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Yes; I'm sure of it. 'Tis in your arm; you cannot poise your sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: It is too true: your point has hit me thro' the guard: I'm at your mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I am at your's, dear Charles, for pardon and forgiveness: now I retract my words, and blush for having used them—Let me bind up your wrist; here is a handkerchief—Shall I call for assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: No, no; a scratch; 'tis nothing. It scarce bleeds—Hark! somebody is at the door—Take up the swords.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: —Let me in; I pray you, Gentlemen, let me in. I am Sheva, your friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Open the door, Frederic.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Dear me! dear me! what have you been about? Do you come into a public tavern, and lock yourselves up to be private?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Perhaps we did not wish the world to know the silly business we have been engag'd in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
Gootness defend me! is it come to this? Have I been studying how to make you happy, whilst you were striving how to make me wretch∣ed? What a strange world is this! Are you not friends? Are you not brothers? Is that a reason you shou'd quarrel? And if you differ, must you fight? Can your swords argue better than their masters? You call that an affair of honor, I sup∣pose; under your favor I do not think it a very
honorable affair; 'tis only giving a fine name to a foul deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Custom has gloss'd it over, and we are slaves to custom.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: I ask your pardon; I am only a poor Jew, a stranger in your country, and have not yet been taught to reverence all your customs. Goot lack, goot lack! what is the matter with your wrist?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Nothing to signify; a trifling scratch.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: A scratch you call it; that is a wound in common language: I pray you come to my poor house, and let that scratch be heal'd; you had great care for me, let me have some for you: that is my sense of an affair of honor: to pay the debt that I do owe to you and to your fader, who pre∣serv'd my life in Spain, that is my point of honor.—Come, come, let us depart; this is no place to talk in; take up your swords, I hope we have no further use for them.
SP.STAGE: Sir STEPHEN BERTRAM and Mrs. GOODISON.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Your son is not at home, Sir Stephen, but Mrs. Bertram is; and if you will allow me to call her down, I'm sure she will be happy to pay her duty to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: A moment's patience, Mrs. Goodison—You seem much interested for this young bride, your lodger.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P:
It is impossible to be otherwise. She
has beauty to engage the eye, and manners to inte∣rest the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Some pride of family about her, I should guess; a little of her brother's vivacity perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: None that appears: mildness and modesty, and every gentle grace, seem inherently her own.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Be pleas'd to tell her I attend to pay my compliments; and as young ladies' characters are not so easily develop'd in the company of their mo∣thers, I shou'd be glad she wou'd allow me to con∣fer with her alone. [Exit Mrs. GOOD. Now I shall have this mystery unravel'd. Saunders's notion, that the fortune comes from Sheva, is ro∣mantic in the extreme, Why shou'd he portion her? She has no Jew's blood in her veins we'll hope; and as to a deception, that he dare not prac∣tise—She comes!—By heavens! a lovely creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You honor me most highly, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Not so, Madam, the honor is confer'd on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: How have I merited this condescension?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Call it not condescension: it is no more than is due from one, who is proud to embrace the title you have allow'd him to assume.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: This is beyond my hopes. Will you permit me then to call myself your daughter, and entreat a blessing and a pardon on my knees?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P:
Not for the world in that submissive posture. All you can ask is granted with acknow∣ledgments
on my part for the happiness you have bestowed upon my son—Had certain circumstances occur'd before your marriage, that have since turn'd up, I presume you wou'd not have precipi∣tated matters, at least not in the secret manner they were carried.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: What circumstances, Sir, may you al∣lude to?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: The death, as I suppose, in your fa∣mily—

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Good Heaven forbid! What death? My brother—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: No! your brother, Madam, no! Pray be not thus alarm'd!—I know your brother's cir∣cumstances too well to suppose your sudden fortune cou'd proceed from him—Perhaps some distant re∣lation, or some friend may have bequeath'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: What? let me ask. I know of no be∣quest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Call it a gift then, a donation on your marriage—It must have been an agreeable surprize to my son to have been presented with a fortune so expected.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P:
I am loth to think Sir Stephen Bertram can descend to ridicule my poverty: that I shou'd be regarded by you as an unwelcome intruder upon your family I can well believe; that you wou'd point your whole resentment against me alone, and spare your son, is all that I dare wish at present: my future hope aspires no higher than by perseve∣rance in my duty as a wife to merit your opinion, so as in time you may acknowledge me as your
daughter. Conscious that I have incurr'd your dis∣pleasure, I shall patiently endeavour to soften it by submission and obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Madam, that answer is at once so paci∣fying and so candid, that if the information I have had of your being possess'd of ten thousand pounds for your fortune, be salse, tho' I thought I had pretty strong evidence of it—

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Impossible!—I'm sure your son, I'm sure my brother never told you this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: I cannot say they did.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: No, I'll engage for them they wou'd dis∣dain so gross and palpable a deceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Well, be it as it may, with or without a fortune, portion'd or pennyless, I feel myself so irresistibly impell'd to open my arms to you as a father, that whether Sheva has or has not deceiv'd me, I here deposit my resentment, and by what I experience of your power over my heart, most thoroughly acquit my son for having surrender'd his.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: It is the impulse of your own generosity; not any impression of my giving, that moves your heart to pity and forgiveness.—But who is Sheva, that you seem to point at as the author of this falsehood?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Sheva the Jew—Surely you know the man.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Thank Heaven I do not: I can safely say I never to my recollection heard his name before. Some vile impostor, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P:
Not quite that, tho' bad enough to be
so treated, if he has practis'd this deceit on me. Sheva is my broker, your husband knows him well, a miserly methodical old Alley drudge, who shew'd me what I believ'd a true receipt for ten thousand pounds vested in your name in the funds—One of my people wou'd have persuaded me it was his own voluntary benefaction—but if you don't know him, never saw him, never heard his name, the thing's impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Totally so, without one ray of probabi∣lity: the man is either mad or mischievous: no Jew of that or any other name do I know; nay, I question if I ever exchang'd a word with any one of the nation in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Your merit then, and not your fortune, shall endear you to me. I will strike out ten thou∣sand pounds, that I perceive you are not possess'd of, and write in ten thousand graces, which I perceive you are possess'd of, and so balance the account.—Now, Saunders, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sean.
SP.P: Your son requested me to give this letter into your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Step.
SP.P: No, no—there needs no letter—Tell him it is done; say that you found me conquer'd in less time than he was. Bid him make haste hither in person before I run away with his wife; and let him write no more letters, for I won't read a word of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Won't you be pleas'd to open your letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P:
Positively I will not read it, because
Frederic shall not have to say that his rhetoric had any share in making me a convert. If it is, as I suppose, a recital of your graces and good quali∣ties, I do not want his description to assist my sense of what I see; but if you have a wish to see your own fair person painted by his hand, you are wel∣come to indulge it—Break the seal—

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: 'Tis short—I'll read it to you—“I am this instant summoned by Charles Ratcliffe on a point of honor, sword to sword.”—Oh Heavens!—I can no more—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: What is it? what alarms you?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Oh! that letter, that letter!—My hus∣band and my brother—or one or both have fallen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Merciful Powers forbid it!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Stop not to read it; fly, and take me with you, plant me between them: I am the cause of quarrel; let the sword, that aims to pierce a heart dearer than my own, lodge in my guilty bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Oh horrible to thought!—Hark, who is coming?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: The messenger of death—Let him not speak; his very look will kill me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: My love, my life, my ever dear Eliza!—

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Where is your wound? Are you not dying? What is become of Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Here is your happy brother: all is well.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: We are both here, with friendly hearts and joyful news to greet you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Don't speak of joy too soon: t'will overthrow my senses—Let me survey you both. Don't deceive me; you have wounds about you—Ah! Charles, what's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: The least, but luckiest wound that ever man receiv'd: this little glance of your brave hus∣band's sword disarm'd me of my weapon, and both our rash hearts of their anger. Now lay aside your fears, and prepare yourself for wonders.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Oh! Sir, I have offended you; but—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: But what? You have an advocate, that makes all hearts her own. Spare your appeal; you will but waste your words.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Here comes my mother: bear up, Eliza; say not a word of what has pass'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Oh! my dear madam, I have joy to give you—Let me present you to my Frederic's father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Yes, madam; and the greatest joy that son ever conferr'd upon me is the title he has given me to claim a father's share with you in this angel of a daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Such she has been to me. I am blest to hear you say that you approve her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Frederic, give me your hand—If you had brought me half the Indies with a wife, I shou'd not have join'd your hand to her's with such sincere delight.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: How generous is that declaration!—Now, Charles, 'tis time to introduce our friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: What does he mean, Eliza?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I know no more than you: Some new wonder, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Hah! Sheva here? This is indeed a wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: This is the man—My benefactor; your's, Eliza; Frederic's; your's, dear mother; all man∣kind's: The widow's friend, the orphan's father, the poor man's protector, the universal philan∣thropist.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Hush, hush! you make me hide my face.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: Ah, Sir, 'tis now too late to cover your good deeds: You have long mask'd your charities beneath this humble seeming, and shrunk back from actions princes might have gloried in: You must now face the world, and transfer the blush from your own cheeks to their's, whom prejudice had taught to scorn you. For your single sake we must reform our hearts, and inspire them with candor towards your whole nation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P:
Enough, Enough! more than enough—I pray you spare me: I am not used to hear the voice of praise, and it oppresses me: I shou'd not know myself, if you were to describe me; I have a register within, in which these merits are not
noted. Simply I am an honest man, no more; fair in my dealings, as my good patron here, I hope, can witness.—That lady, I believe, is Mrs. Ratcliffe: She does not know me: I will not touch upon a melancholy subject, else I cou'd tell a story—Merciful Heaven! what horrors was I snatch'd from by her husband, now, alas! no more!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Oh, gracious Powers!—The Jew of Cadiz—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: The very same—your debtor in no less a sum than all that I possess, the earnings of a life preserv'd first by your husband, and now again by your son. Why am I prais'd then, if I am merely honest, and discharge my debts?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: Ah! now the mystery's solv'd. The ten thousand pounds were your's.—Give them to Rat∣cliffe; I will have nothing from fortune, where nature gives so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: That is a noble speech—but monies does not lessen merit, at least not always, as I hope, for Mr. Ratcliffe's sake; for he is heir of all that I possess.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: What can I say? My heart's too full for utterance. O Charles, the fortunes of your house revive; surely the blessed spirit of your de∣parted father now sympathizes in our joy. Re∣member, son, to whom you owe this happiness, and emulate his virtues.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.P: If I forget to treat my fortune, as becomes the son of such a father, and the heir of such a be∣nefactor, your warning will be my condemnation.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: That it will never be: the treasure that integrity has collected, cannot be better lodg'd than in the hands of honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir S.
SP.P: It is a mine of wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheva.
SP.P: Excuse me, goot Sir Stephen, it is not a mine, for it was never out of sight of those who search'd for it: the poor man did not dig to find it; and where I now bestow it, it will be found by him again. I do not bury it in a synagogue or any other costly pile; I do not waste it upon vanity or public works: I leave it to a charitable heir, and build my hospital in the human heart.

LG.L: TRUTH has declar'd, and question it none can▪
WOMAN was once a rib of Lordly MAN;
And some perhaps wou'd risque a little pain
To hitch that rib into its place again;
For let the heart-ache, or what aught betide,
They're sure to trace it to the peccant side,
Till fixt at length they centre all the blame
In that one rib, from whence the Woman came,
Now this is downright prejudice and spleen,
A plea for thrusting us behind the scene;
And there we stood for many a long long age,
Not let to steal one foot upon the Stage,
Till now, when all their tyrant acts are past,
Curtsying we come, like EPILOGUE, at last;
And you so little are inclin'd to rout us,
You wonder how your fathers did without us.
Sure we can lightlier touch those feeling parts,
That twine about the region of your hearts;
Passion, that from the lips of Woman flows,
Warm to Man's soul with magic switness goes;
And tho' the sphere be small in which we move,
Great is the recompence when you approve.
Whilst Nature and your candour hold their course,
So long our Charter will remain in force;
Nor will you grudge the privilege you gave,
Till we forget to smile upon the Brave.
Still in the slipp'ry path, that brings us near
Forbidden precincts, we must tread with fear,
Does my weak cast in tragic pathos lie?
Why then so dismal, gentle Poet, why?
In mirth oft' times the nuptial knot I've ty'd,
But never was till now a Mourning Bride.
If to my share some moving speeches fall,
"Look in my face, and they'll not move at all."
Yet, not to drop at once ELIZA'S stile,
One word in earnest, and without a smile—
Thro' all the characters of varied life,
All the fond casts of Parent, Child, or Wife,
What part soe'er our Author has assign'd,
To that we must conform with patient mind;
So at the Drama's close when we appear,
We may obtain a parting plaudit here.
